title: Springs in series - effective spring constant

content.question: A block hangs at rest at the end of an ideal spring with spring constant <math alttext="k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> as shown in Scenario <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. In Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, a second ideal spring with a spring constant <math alttext="k sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, where <math alttext="k sub 2 is not equal to k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>â‰ </mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, is then added above the original spring and the block again hangs at rest. Which statement best describes the equivalent spring constant <math alttext="k sub equivalent" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></math> in Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="k sub equivalent is greater than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because in Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> both springs pull up on the block.

<math alttext="k sub equivalent is greater than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the combination of both springs will stretch more than the original spring.

<math alttext="k sub equivalent is less than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the same weight will cause more stretching with two springs than with one.

<math alttext="k sub equivalent is less than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because in Scenario <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> both springs stretch by the same amount.

content.answer: <math alttext="k sub equivalent is less than k sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>k</mi><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>k</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> because the same weight will cause more stretching with two springs than with one.
